query: What did Barry Hughes think of the law as it currently stood?
summary: Barry Hughes believed that the law should reflect contemporary society and the law was evolutionary in nature. In that regard, it could be argued that children had fewer rights than adults. But the more general criminal legislation, such as the Offences Against the Person Act, did provide specifically for adults and children alike not to be subject to physical assault.

query: What are the implications for implementing the legislation in Wales for the divergence between the law in England and Wales?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there is a spectrum of offending. In England and Wales, the limit for having micrograms of alcohol in your breath is 35 µg in 100 ml of breath. Across the border in Scotland, it drops to 22 µg. In terms of the practical application of the legislation in Wales, it would almost certainly work on the basis that the number of offences was likely to be very small and they would probably have two or three specialists trained in this so that any case that came through would go to people who had got a close network and could talk with each other.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the divergence of criminal law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought they would need to update the guidance, and it went back to the application of the evidential stage, before the public interest stage. They might have some light-touch guidance around that. When it comes to the public interests stage, that's a little more specialist and they needed to develop more with respect to that.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before they make their final decision?
summary: Barry Hughes did not think that it would necessarily be helpful to see the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before they make their final decision. What they would envisage was that they would simply want to take the present public interest factors, which were set out, in his view, very clearly in the code for Crown prosecutors, and they would provide a degree of detail around those that relates more specifically to the issues that they were discussing here. And they would need to work that up as they went along, and

query: What did Sian Gwenllian AM think about the criminal law in Wales and England diverging in this particular instance?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked Barry Hughes if there were other offences in Wales that didn't exist in England, but they didn't crop up very often. Barry Hughes answered that there were some, but the fact that you drive across the border into Scotland and commit an offence that you won't commit in England was possibly more significant for the general public. So, if they remove the defence of reasonable chastisement, in a sense that alters some things but it didn't alter the basic responsibility of the prosecution, which was to establish its case beyond a reasonable doubt.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of intervention earlier on when talking about neighbour disputes?
summary: From the perspective of the CPS, Barry Hughes was not sure how intervention might work better earlier on, even at the point of the knock at the door. Unlike in many other jurisdictions, they had no power whatsoever to direct the police, so if the police decided not to investigate, it would be their responsibility to disprove that.

query: What did Barry Hughes answer when Suzy Davies AM asked about keeping a clear record of any cases that were referred to the CPS from the police?
summary: Suzy Davies AM thought that it was really helpful to know that the difficulties of dealing with the culture change, which was what the Minister's effectively after here, was that they were still talking about it in the context of criminal legislation. Barry Hughes answered that they would be doing that in consultation with interested parties and stakeholders. They would keep a manual log of every referral. The numbers would be very small, which means they would keep an clear track on those and, obviously, they would wish to keep the situation under review, and they would reach a period of time after whatever—12, 18 months, maybe 24 months—where they would look back to see how they were doing. The value that would derive from this legislation was the message that it sends out.

query: What did the public interest test take into account when deciding whether to go forward with a prosecution?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there was a long list of matters that they took into account. Some of them were fairly obvious, such as previous convictions. If someone's got previous convictions for doing something wrong, it's more likely they're going to be prosecuted the next time. But there was no part of the law that said that prosecution would always follow. The essence of it was about proportionality, and trying to come up with an approach that was proportionate to the offending. There was a section about impact on the victim. It was not determinative, nor was it determinative in cases where we prosecute for adult defendants inflicting some form of assault upon adult victims.

query: What did Barry Hughes say about out-of-court disposals?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, this was primarily a matter for the police, because there were a great many offences or reports of crime that did not reach the CPS because they were dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. Offences that the police referred to us for a charging decision would generally be offences where they felt that there should be a prosecution rather than an out of court disposal. There would also be cases where it was genuinely very difficult to assess what's the best approach, in which case they would have a conversation with them, a meaningful conversation, about what was the best way to approach that particular case.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the importance of raising awareness of the unintended consequences?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the greater the level of awareness, the more likely it was that the Act, if passed, would achieve its intentions. So, raising awareness was important, and he saw, and was pleased to see, that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation, which was now going through, reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales, and the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something which was potentially divisive.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the risk of malicious reporting against parents involved in private family law cases?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the risk of malicious reporting against parents involved in private family law cases. Barry Hughes answered that it was not something that would cause concern, simply because they already had a well-developed approach to dealing with the way in which they evaluated the evidence from parties who may well have a particular position that they wanted to reinforce, sometimes through exaggeration of basic facts and sometimes through fabrication.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the potential barrier to implementing the proposed law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that there was a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecute 5 per cent of those in any given year. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions was not a reason not to say that they shouldn't signify that certain behaviour was or was not acceptable. The criminal law provided a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand. There was a shortage of registered intermediaries in Wales, and the Ministry of Justice had taken action to deal with that. Now, of course, if they were to decide not to do that anymore, they would have a problem, but in turn they would be looking to recruit more people into those positions.

query: Summarize the discussion about parallelization
summary: The team was discussing how to handle the task of parallelization. The professor informed the team that the team had put in an order for twelve new machines to use as a compute farm. Each machine had an attribute which was the name of itself and the team could specify the amount of memory the machine had, what its speed was, and what its operating system was. query: What did PhD A think about speech enhancement algorithms?
summary: PhD A explained that after the submission of the Aurora submission, he had been working on some other speech enhancement algorithms. He had been taking spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering from other submissions and applying them to his model. He found that the baseline itself improved by fifty percent by plugging in an LDA. He also found that he had to retune the time constants of the on-line normalization.

query: What did PhD D think about spectral subtraction?
summary: PhD D informed the team that spectral subtraction had finally been shown to improve on the sixty-four hertz cut-off. However, it was still slightly worse for well-matched. The team thought that the main mismatch was coming from the amount of noise and the silence frames.

query: What did the Professor think about noise?

He also suggested that they could try using a combination of different techniques.

query: What did the Professor think about voice-unvoice-silence silence?

query: Summarize the discussion about the belief-net
summary: The team discussed the basic features of the belief-net, including whether the user's budget may influence the outcome of decisions. The professor suggested that the team should spend at least part of the time trying to build the influence links, which means that they should know which sets of things are relevant to which decisions and which ones are not. They should also decide what kinds of belief nodes are needed in order to do what they need to do.

query: What did the Professor think about the ontology?
summary: The professor thought that the ontology could be used as an intermediate node to allow the belief-net to have properties and the properties are filled in from ontology items. The ontology can also be used to help the decision-net know what kind of place a person is going to enter. The professor also suggested that the endpoint decision should be based on three separate considerations, accessibility, landmark, and accessible. The decision node should have properties that fit into the decision node and then as part of the outer controlling conditioning of this thing those properties would be set.

query: What did the professor suggest about the structure of the entity?
summary: The professor suggested that the entity could be regarded as a vector of several possible things, like Gothic churches versus Baroque townhouses versus a landmark. The professor also suggested that it could be a landmark at the same time as doing other things, such as selling things or exhibiting things. In order to make the model more compact, the professor proposed that the model could be divided into three parts, each of which could be computed by a different person.

query: What did the Professor think about the Go-there decision?
summary: The professor thought that the Go-there decision should have a node from the discourse and the endpoint should have the EVA values. The professor also thought that there should be a link between the endpoint and the user, so that the user can only enter a place if they are not too tired to do so and also have the money to perform it if it costs something.

query: What did the Professor think about the semantics of the discourse?
summary: The professor explained that the semantics that the team would get out of the discourse would be of values that went into the various discourse-based decision nodes. The semantics would come from something about the user, the situation, and the discourse history. The professor thought that it was important not to have loops because it would not be well defined and things would not converge if there were loops.

query: What did the team discuss about the probability distribution?
summary: The team wanted to know how they could get a valid probability distribution for each belief-net node. The professor suggested that they could specify the conditional property of each node given its parents, which would allow them to calculate the probability of the given node. They could also specify the probabilities of each of the different inputs, which could be combined mathematically in a weighted combination.

query: Summarize the discussion about the features in the belief-net.

query: What did PhD D think about the model?
summary: PhD D informed the team that the on-line normalization was not working well and that they needed to improve the model. PhD D explained that the model was starting from the beginning of the utterance and using initial values that were the global mean and variances measured across the whole database. The model was not performing as well as it could.

query: What did the Professor think about experiments?
summary: The professor thought that the team should choose the experiments carefully so that they can get key questions answered before the meeting with Hynek on Monday. The team was concerned that the LDA filter was not used as an additional feature and that it was throwing out chunks of data. The professor explained that the median filter was enforcing a continuity of the data.

query: What did the professor think about detecting silence?
summary: The professor thought that it would be a good idea to detect silence because it would reduce the number of bits that had to be transmitted. He also thought that the neural net would help with the task since it would not cut speech off a lot. However, he did not think that it was feasible to parallelize the training because the model would be stuck by the HTK trainings.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the market situation and the decision on the remote control concept.
summary: The group discussed the market situation and made some changes in the remote control design. Ease of use was important, innovation was more important and fancy look and feel was even more important. The group agreed that the feel of the material had to be spongy and the corporate colours should be grey and yellow. The younger target group liked more colourful objects and the older group preferred dark colours and simple shapes. The team also agreed that they should provide both for the young and the old what they like.

query: Summarize the discussion about the features of the new remote control.
summary: The group discussed the features of the remote control, including the shape, the colour, the material, the shape of the casing, the energy sources, the fancy look and feel and the ease of use. The group agreed that the new remote control would be curved in two and three dimensions and would have an advanced shape. It would have voice recognition and a round button for the channel programming and volume. There would also be a kinetic energy supply.

query: What did the group discuss about the scroll-wheel when discussing the functional design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the scroll-wheel was new and attractive to the young customers. However, it was not suitable for the remote control because it was curved and there were no flat areas where it could be incorporated. Also, the group did not want to use LCD displays because it would be too costly. Therefore, they decided to use push buttons instead of LCD displays.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the energy source and the casing material of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer preferred the more reliable and cheaper battery with solar cell solution for the energy because it was more reliable, cheaper and robust. The kinetic thing was more advanced, but Industrial Designer thought they should combine it with batteries because it would not be too advanced. The group agreed to skip the titanium stuff and use wood or something like that.

query: Summarize the decision of the product evaluation.
summary: The team decided to use a single-curved case with rubber and to use company colours such as black and red, grey and yellow. The energy source would be traditional batteries and solar. The case would be curved and the buttons would be in yellow and grey. The corporate identity should be in the product and the cover should be full colour with such an image.

query: What did the group discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: The group decided to use a scroll-wheel, voice recognition, a plastic cover with rubber finishing, and some additional buttons. They also decided not to use LCD because their customers specifically asked for the spongy feel and that's what they got with rubber. The group also agreed that the drawings on the buttons would disappear eventually, so they could use plastic buttons instead.

query: What did Dafydd Evans and Sian Gwenllian think of employers' attitude towards the Welsh baccalaureate qualification?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that employers did not think that employers had a clear understanding of what the Welsh baccalaureate qualification meant or what it included at present. They were having enough headache getting around the differences with apprenticeships and the levy between England and Wales, and changes to qualifications. So, no, they didn't think that the employers understood the value or what they were trying to achieve through the Welsh qualification at present, which was putting a lot of pressure on in terms of bureaucracy and the student getting all the information together at the end of the year.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of improving employers' understanding of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans suggested that they need to review the qualification, and the voice of employers should be a key part of that review, so that employability skills and entrepreneurial skills have more of a role within the qualification. The aim of the baccalaureate was an excellent one, but they had lost their way in terms of what they did present at the end of the day, and having more input from employers would be a great help. And the only way they would get employer buy-in was if they felt ownership of what was being done.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think about the problems with the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that one of the problems was that there were a number of priorities. It was a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a C grade in the core subjects. However, if getting the qualification was how they got the money, then they might be tempted to go for it. The Welsh baccalaureate, where it worked really well, did help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it was not for everyone, because some people had to do the other things.

query: What did the group discuss about the different levels of the Welsh baccalaureate valued by further education professionals?
summary: According to Nick Brazil, the Welsh baccalaureate was not what they would call a crowd puller in colleges, but at level 3 it was more, especially for A-levels, because it could help them get into university. So, to get into some areas, like dentistry, for example, and some of the other Seren-type activities, four A-Levels was better.

query: What did Kay Martin think about universities and the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Kay Martin thought that universities in the main did not believe the value of the Welsh baccalaureate, especially the experience they had with some of their learners to go to Russell Group universities. However, some of the universities were not valuing the Welsh degree. They did allow sometimes that you could drop a grade. And the important point that Dafydd raised was that there was a lot of repetition there in school, pre 16 to post 16 at those levels as well. So, they needed to consider that.

query: What did Julie Morgan think of the baccalaureate when talking about its comparison with other qualifications?
summary: Julie Morgan thought that the baccalaureate was trying to be all things to all men. At one end of the spectrum it was a rigorous qualification that stood up to a Russell university's expectations, and on the other hand, it aimed to develop softer skills and employment skills for people going into work from a vocational area. Therefore, it was comparable, as long as it was right for that learner's future. But if a learner wanted to go into a particular sector and the Welsh bac was not accepted, then it was not comparable. For the vocational students, some things like the Career Ready programme, which was used in other colleges, and WorldSkills, where all colleges had really been pushing to get more learners into WorldSkill at national and international level, were more valuable to those learners and they were more able and talented vocational learners.

query: What did Nick Brazil think of the baccalaureate approach when talking about skills to be developed?
summary: The baccalaureate approach was best at producing independent, inquiry-based learners who had the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. The chances were that they had lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. Nick Brazil thought there was a need to relook at it to make sure those skills were being developed fully.

query: What did the group discuss about the decision not to offer baccalaureate?
summary: According to Kay Martin, the decision in individual colleges not to offer baccalaureate was down to the opportunity that it presented them to attract students, particularly from sixth forms, where students may be obliged to do the bac. In the majority of colleges across Wales, it was absolutely not used as a recruitment tool, because most of them, as you see, they value the Welsh bac in many cases. They don't say, "Come to us and you don't have to do A-Levels, because they say it's compulsory, unless you're in the Seren group."

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of the baccalaureate when Suzy Davies AM suggested that some of the more able and talented STEM students, in particular—who were needed in your sector, after all—might be deterred from doing those four A-levels because of the
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, it was not a case of squeezing things out. It was part of what the college's curriculum offered—there was no doubt about that—and then people made a choice according to what they needed to do to actually progress to the what they need to do in their future. The qualifications were well catered for. There was a big range, and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. So, the Welsh baccalaureate started to do some of those things at different levels. They were certainly not selling it, 'Come-to-we; you don't do the baccalureate'. It was about that mix. Suzy Davies AM suggested that some of the more able and talented STEM students, in particular—who were needed in your sector, after all—might be deterred from doing those four A-levels because of the bac, because, presumably, you need a mix of these talents?

query: What did Nick Brazil say about the range of qualification opportunities for learners?
summary: According to Nick Brazil, in terms of their offer, they offer a range in the curriculum. There are some places in sixth forms now, where certain qualifications may not be offered now because of the need to pick up an extra—Welsh bac. So, what parents and learners are looking for is for the range of options. If they don't offer the full range, which, sometimes—if they, obviously, limit and make qualifications compulsory, that can limit the choice of opportunities as well.

query: What did the group discuss about improving the status and perception of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that there were certainly instances of young people coming in with quite a negative attitude originally, originally, to the Welsh baccalaureate and taking it on board. But where they were delivering it well, well contextualised, they had really enjoyed the experience, and very much valued the experience. However, it was very difficult for them, as institutions, to change the perception. Dr Rachel Bowen thought that it did make it into quite an intensive selling process for colleges when they had got to overcome that negative perception. As people have said already, it is possible to talk parents and learners round, but then that's time spent having to do that selling job when they should be talking about other things.

query: What did Kay Martin and Dafydd Evans discuss about the universal adoption?
summary: Kay Martin thought that if the qualification had changed into something that wasn't 100 per cent what they thought it should be, then they had stopped the universal adoption, but that didn't really seem to be happening on the ground. Therefore, they were trying to do what's in the best interests of the learner, but they were not sure at the moment. They needed to spend less time in checking what they had done on assessment and more time in the doing, and the experiential learning that they needed to do, rather than it being too much of a paper exercise.

query: What did Kirsty say about the curriculum changes that they were proposing?
summary: According to Kirsty, there had been broad support for the curriculum changes that they were proposing. There was a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity as possible. Then, below that, they were going to legislate for a number of the cross-curricular aspects—so, literacy, the numeracy and the digital competency—as well as some elements where they had already said that they would make that statutory, so, for instance, above and beyond what Graham Donaldson would have put in his original reports. Next, they would be looking to include in the legislation provision for a statutory framework setting out their approach to progression in each of the AoLE areas.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the religious education and relationships and sexuality education?
summary: According to Kirsty, the 'what matters' were the articulation of the big ideas. They were always intended to represent, as a whole, the learning that every learner should get. There were mixed views on the inclusion of a range of faiths and world religions included in that area of learning. And there were many responses that were concerned about and emphasised the need to respect parents' views.

query: What is the timetable for the Bill itself and for seeking Royal Assent for that?
summary: According to Kirsty, the expectation is that they will publish a final version of the curriculum in January 2020, so schools will then have the opportunity to be really engaging in it. There were some issues raised about potential challenges with staff in talking about issues that they perhaps personally did not agree with with regard to this curriculum. With regard to guaranteed access to a full curriculum, there were strong views that, again, it should be parents, and parents alone, that made decisions about whether their children should have access to the entirety curriculum rather than schools or the state setting those rules.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the effect of the curriculum on equity?
summary: Hefin David AM asked about the connection between Welsh Government and local government and the concerns that the Welsh Local Government Association and the Association of Directors of Education Wales raised. Kirsty Williams AM answered that there was no evidence that the curriculum could exacerbate segregation within schools between different groups of pupils. However, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity because the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and what would have a bigger impact on children who were in danger of being left behind, were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. First of all, the teachers were absolutely crucial to this. They spend a lot of time thinking about accountability and how they were going to be held accountable for their practice, but, again, what they wanted to do was provide reassurance that they were devising an accountability regime for our system that was in line with the aims and objectives of the new curriculum and put them in the mainstream thought and reform process across the world of progressive education systems. Then they had got issues around assessment and accountability.

query: What did Kirsty Williams and Steve Davies discuss about assessment?
summary: Kirsty Williams explained that the particular focus of this year's conference was on the issue of assessment and they were joined by colleagues from Scotland, from Ireland, from Iceland, from Finland, from Saskatchewan, from Nova Scotia and from Uruguay. Although their curriculum was not a copycat, they had been able to learn from, and they had had people who had been deeply involved in the Scottish experience as part of some of their curriculum and assessment groups and some of the advice that they've had in terms of developing coherence. One of the lessons learned from Scotland was that they spent too much time on curriculum content rather than assessment. What they learnt was to actually get a smaller group to develop those materials and look to engage through cluster groups.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the investment in professional learning?
summary: Kirsty Williams AM first of all agreed that it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. The four regional consortia were working together to provide consistency for classroom teachers and teaching assistants, and then the next stage of that development was for subject specifics. The next stages would be much more focused on individual AoLE and area-specific professional learning. Then Kirsty Williams explained that they were looking at developing potentially a stronger set of support, again on a national basis, for those who were newly qualified, beginning their teaching career, because they didn't think they had done that on a consistently good level across the country. They were also working with the regions to revisit and improve their coaching and mentoring schemes that they had across the system. Finally, there was a national approach in terms of leadership.

query: Summarize the discussion about the issue of teachers who are not trained in Wales.
summary: Kirsty Williams explained that each school that participates in the innovation schools programme gets £30,000. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model. Each school is part of a network that links to it, and they gauge (1) the level of activity in it, (2) the outcomes of that work. They don't have a roll-call against all schools, but they require them, or request of them that they keep us informed of the networks.

query: What did Kirsty think of the accountability of schools when talking about parents' views on assessment methods?
summary: According to Kirsty, parents will always be interested in how the overall institution is doing. But the conversations I had with parents, and I certainly feel this myself as a parent—I'm interested in the child's learning and progression. And that should be the purpose for assessment. The purpose for categorization is not to make a judgment on a school in the sense of a league table; it's a triage process, categorisation. So, absolutely, you would expect teachers to be sharing information around assessment methods, whichever type they used, with parents to describe and to inform parents about what happens next for their child.

query: How would the general public understand the accountability regime?
summary: According to Kirsty, the first part of the accountability regime would be the professionalism of individual members of staff. The measures would still consider reflection on progress of children, but it would also have reviews of mental health, well-being, how it approaches that and things that it wanted to do. The outcome of the self-evaluation would be a school development plan. The schools' ability would be judged by Estyn.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the Welsh dimension in the new curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought it was really important that whatever resources they had to support the Welsh dimension were really, really, broad and not confined to specific areas. The continuum for language would have to be contextualised depending on the setting where a child was being taught, and there would be progression points on that continuum that would be there to show progression both in Welsh language and in the English language.

query: How would Kirsty Williams AM guarantee that all children and young people would take part in physical activity under the new curriculum for Wales?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM wanted to know whether all children and young people, where appropriate, would take part in physical activity under the new curriculum for Wales. Kirsty Williams AM answered that all children would be given that opportunity, because if they were not then that school would be in breach of the expectations that would be set out in statute. However, how would they monitor it?

query: What arrangements would be in place to ensure that pupils could benefit from the new curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, statutory and non-statutory provision had been involved in the development of the curriculum because, of course, some of this was going to be delivered in the non-Statutory sector. But FE have been involved with this process from the very beginning. They would be setting a minimum standard around the purposes, around the cross-cutting themes and health and well-being, and then there would be an expectation that in conjunction with the child and the family an appropriate addition would be put in place to meet the needs of that child, recognising that they could have very different needs.

query: Summarize the discussion about the agenda of the meeting.
summary: Project Manager introduced that they were going to make a remote control, which had to be original, trendy, user-friendly, detailed and detailed. The team would have three steps of making the remote control. There would be functional design, conceptual design and conceptual design. The functional design would include the functional design of the components and the properties and the specifications of the user interface. The conceptual design would be about the functional and conceptual aspects of the remote controls. The detailed design would consist of the material, the properties, the material and the material of the product.

query: What did the group draw on the whiteboard?
summary: Marketing drew a fish and Industrial Designer drew a worm. User Interface drew a dog. Project Manager suggested that the animal should be an animal that lives in the water, but User Interface insisted that it should not be a snake or a snake because the water was important. After that, Project Manager asked the group to make a new blank new blank page.

query: Summarize the discussion about the cost and profit of the remote control.
summary: The team agreed that they had to sell this remote control for about twenty-five Euros and make a profit of fifty million Euros. The production cost were about half the price of selling price, so the profit would be about 25 Euros. They had to use a big market in Europe, so they would have to use VCR and DVD players. There would be a lot of buttons on the remote control, so it would be hard to design a universal remote control.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested making the remote control in the same style as the television, but User Interface rejected this idea because they didn't have the same television all the time, so that's no matter. User Interface also suggested making it clear so that kids and the elderly could use it easily, but Project Manager disagreed with this idea and insisted that it must be a very good control so that it could be used from everywhere in the house and the infrared thing must be from very good quality. Finally, User Interface suggested that they could make it smaller and more trendy by making it foldable.

query: What did the group discuss about putting the remote control in a recharger or a home station?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested putting the remote control in a recharger or a home station. Project Manager thought it was a good idea because lots of people lost their remote control and didn't know where it was, so it would be good to put it always at the same place. User Interface thought the basic things should be put on the same places, like on off button on top and the TV channels one two three four as a block, and then the volume obviously on top so that users can see. However, the price of the rechargers was not clear and they had to do a lot of testing to see if it worked.

query: What did the group discuss about the user requirements and specifications of the remote control?
summary: Marketing asked the group to think about the user requirements and specifications, such as whether it's for TV, a DVD player, a DVD player, all that things together, and what kind of buttons they need on the remote control. Project Manager asked what's in the market, what's normal, what kinds of buttons do people have and what they want to do with it. User Interface also wrote down some ideas on what the team could do with the remote controls.

query: What did PhD F think about using the corpus?
summary: PhD F thought that the corpus should be used for multiple purposes because it would be expensive to put together a single one-off meeting. The team also discussed the feasibility of collecting more data from different kinds of meetings, such as the front-end meeting and the networking group meetings.

query: Summarize the discussion about meeting space and logistics
summary: The team thought that they were slowly getting to the point where they had enough room to record meetings. They were getting more space on the current disk, but they needed to figure out how to use it. The team was concerned that the SPINE data was moving to a non-backed-up disk, so they were going to have to burn an extra CD-ROM to backup it. They also wanted to make sure that the kind of group they were getting was the right one and that they didn't waste a lot of time and overhead in bringing people down.

query: Summarize the discussion on overlapping zones
summary: The team discussed how to classify overlapping zones. The team wanted to know what the contribution of each parameter to the process of classify correctly the different parameters was. The professor suggested that they could use a neural net to study the property of the different feat features.

query: What did the Professor think about detecting speaker overlaps?
summary: The professor thought that the main objective of the project was to detect the change, the acoustic change. He thought that if the team did not use a speech recognizer, a broad class of broad-class features would be sufficient to label the different frames. The professor also thought that it would be useful to look at spectral distortion in the PDA to detect speaker overlaps.

query: What did the Professor think about the transcript?
summary: The team discussed the importance of the ability to distinguish between speaker and non-speaker information in the transcript. The professor thought that it was important for the team to have a sense of the context in which the data was being collected. He thought that the team should be aware that it would be difficult to get a full identity for every speaker in the data, but it would not be a bad idea to have an anonymized name for the speaker identifier and also in the text whenever the speaker is mentioned.

query: What did the team discuss about the transcripts?
summary: The team thought that they should not change the names of the speakers in the transcripts because it would be a bad idea to do so. They also wanted to make sure that the data they were collecting would not be used for discourse analysis. The team discussed whether they could bleep out the names from the transcripts or not. The professor suggested that they could use a combination of both.

query: Summarize the discussion about the basic functions of the remote control.
summary: The group discussed the basic functions of the remote control, such as volume, channels, the basic according to, text service options, on-off, and usability. The team agreed to keep it simple and make it special. They also agreed to make it for elderly people because they were more willing to spend more money for something fancy.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: User Interface suggested that the remote control should stand out by having a different shape than usual and be unique with the design. It should also have a menu button, a navigation button and a button to go to the channel you've been before. In addition, it should be able to produce infrared light, which was not visible to the human eye, but it could be integrated with volume and previous and next. The group agreed to keep it simple and standard and integrate it in the design as well.

query: What did the team discuss about the teletext option?
summary: Industrial Designer explained that the chip was producing the pattern when the circuit was closed, so they had to make a chip that produced patterns to send a signal to the infrared bulb. However, Project Manager thought that teletext had become outdated since the popularity of internet. So they decided to skip the teletext option and only make one LED.

query: What did the group discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed to make the remote control more like a mobile phone and to integrate speech recognition into the design. However, they did not want to put the option of speech recognition on the second level because they thought it was too hard to realize that. Also, they agreed to only have simple buttons on the top and the more complicated buttons down there. Besides, they decided to integrate the buttons in the design very much because the usability was not that good.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the basic functional design of the remote control.
summary: The group agreed that the material should be hard plastic, colour changeable and transparent. The buttons should be made of hard plastic and the backlight would be fluorescent. There would be two mute buttons, two on-off buttons, text buttons, mute buttons and a switch channel button. The group also agreed to put the microphone on the back of the remote control and put the scrollwheel on the left side. Besides, there would be a menu button and a scrollwheel with arrows.

query: What did the team discuss about the button design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing proposed to make the remote control with three buttons, red, blue and red, with the basic colours of black, green and yellow. The buttons would be in the shape of the company logo and the colour would be black, yellow and white. There would be one text button, which could be used to search for a page or to switch back to normal teletext. The team agreed to add flashing lights and the background lights from from from the buttons.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation of the remote control.
summary: The team agreed that the remote control was easy to use in the first place, with scrollwheel, backlights, slide, speech function, speech colour, and different fronts for a remote control. But the second layer was not easy to learn, because there were too few information and it was hard to choose what buttons to press for what function. The team also agreed that it was not as fast as a usual remote control, but it was definitely better than the average.

query: Summarize the team discussion about the project evaluation.
summary: The team agreed that there was room for creativity in the remote control. They could make a different style and use a power indicator to see how far the battery was charged up. The team also agreed that the team worked well together. There was a leadership structure with one leader to check the time and make notes.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the new remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the old versions of the remote control were ugly and the LCD screen was unnecessary. User Interface thought that a universal device would be useful, but Industrial Designer pointed out that they didn't have any sizes so they couldn't make a prototype out of this. Then the group had to make a choice between a house and a plant.

query: Summarize Industrial Designer's presentation on the prototype of the remote control.
summary: Industrial Designer presented the prototype of the remote control with a plastic body with a standard colour and a rubberised outer casing. The top screen would be an inset black and white LCD touch screen with a combination of LCD and rubber according to the design. The bottom screen would just contain the standard buttons, like the volume up and down, channel change and on and off, and things to that effect. On the inside, the kinetic batteries would be attached to the flipping open and shut as well, and the infrared sender would be on one of the bottom layers. The remote control would have a standard transmission with the TV using using all the standard chips.

query: Summarize the team's evaluation of the product.
summary: Marketing presented the evaluation criteria based on the market research findings about the spongy texture of the remote control, the fancy look and feel, the technological innovation, the easy to use, and the fruit and vegetable design colours. The team would give a preliminary rating of all those criteria on the whiteboard. Then they would come to a consensus rating between one and seven, where one is true and seven is false.

query: What did the team discuss about the design of the prototype?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the type of button that they were going to use in the bottom half, the material, minimised RSI and made the remote control easy to locate. Project Manager thought that with the amount of stuff they were putting on it, it was feasible to go ahead with the prototype and market it. Also, the team agreed that the prototype would be double-curved with a flat bottom and a slightly flattened bottom so that it could rest.

query: What did the group discuss about the cost of the remote control?
summary: Marketing proposed to change the material of the remote control to a standard one and suggested that they could use a kinetic battery instead of the standard one. However, Industrial Designer pointed out that they were using a very low quantity of rubber compared to plastic, so the cost of the rubber used in the casing would not be included in the total cost. Project Manager agreed and suggested changing the battery to standard.

query: Summarize the wrap up of the meeting.
summary: Industrial Designer thought the meeting went really well. Everyone was listened to and all the points that were raised seemed to have been sorted out, although they didn't quite make the voice recognition in there. Project Manager thought there was constructive feedback by everybody and no one felt like they were shot down. Also, they had a nice teamwork. They came to a very satisfying conclusion that they had done room for creativity and applied it to a different area.

query: What did the group discuss about the project finance?
summary: Marketing thought the project had done very well to get within budget and it still made such an innovative item that people were really gonna want. However, Industrial Designer pointed out that the remit of the project was very specific and they had done what they were required to do. Therefore, they had to look at another project team or a new project to find a way of raising the cash for the project.

query: Summarize the discussion about the reasons for the increase in the number of exclusions from school.
summary: According to Sharon Davies, it was more complicated than just the child behaving in a certain way, or being school-anxious, whatever the issue was. The prevalence of ASD—autism spectrum disorder—and trying to get the learners the right provision was sometimes a challenge. So, they needed to make sure that their staff and their schools were well-equipped to meet these needs, but there would always be some learners who needed more specialist provision. They were working really hard on their exclusions and working with their schools to ensure that the curriculum was broad and balanced, and accounts for every learner within the system.

query: What did the group discuss about the additional learning needs sector and its impact on the system?
summary: According to Sharon Davies, the additional learning needs sector was not adversely affected, but certainly there was pressure, in particular with the new Act coming in, and that was going to place more pressure on the system. The delegation levels were already very high in most authority areas, and they had agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, was devolved to schools. Moreover, the government had been trying to work on the fact that, if children move out of school, the funding follows them. However, it was difficult to know how headteachers and governing bodies would react. If they were under pressure financially or in terms of performance measures, they would react in a particular way.

query: How effective are Torfaen at reintegrating young people into mainstream education?
summary: According to Nick, at least one authority is looking at how they can best retain all pupils in the school setting, but it's early days yet for looking at that. Also, seventy five percent of the users only used ten percent of buttons, so it was a big design issue for the remote control. In addition, thirty four percent of people took too much time to learn to use the new remote control, which was a problem for the older age group. Besides, thirty five and under age group would like a liquid crystal display and speech recognition, which could aid them when they've lost the actual remote control and help them find it. However, Project Manager pointed out that they could cut back on cost if they took a cheaper option which still did the same thing.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the corporate image should be incorporated into the remote control so that it would be fashionable and trendy. They also agreed to have a single model or five, six designs. The features could be essentially the same and the body could look slightly different. The remote control should be easily labelled so that anyone can find it. The group agreed to make it ergonomics-friendly so that users would not have to move their fingers around to change the channel.

query: What did Project Manager suggest to do with the code at the end of programme details?
summary: Project Manager suggested that they could use the code at the end of programme details as an alternative to programming in times when people were not sure if they were going to watch the programme. The code would be a number and users could just press the button on the programme once and it would record that programme when it's on, whereas with a mobile phone, users had to phone the company to get help if they had any problems with it and they had an obligation to help them out. Project Manager also suggested that there could be a customer service number thing that users could phone up and speak to.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The group decided to focus on making the remote control as user-friendly as possible and to get away from the brown rectangles with the same coloured buttons all crammed in on the surface. The remote control would be rechargeable with a docking station so that users wouldn't have to go out buying batteries all the time and it would be cheaper in the long run. The group also agreed to use a flip-screen instead of a big box with lots of things.

query: What did the group discuss about the new project requirements?
summary: Project Manager suggested that the company logo could be incorporated into the design of the remote control, but it was not at the moment a requirement, so it may come round to market research at some point to see what people would like. Project Manager also suggested that there could be an alarm or a beeping for being lost for detection, and a different kind of casings for younger people and sleek ones for sleek ones. The group also agreed that the design should be as simple as possible, and the instruction manual should be made in words so that it would be easier to read.

query: What did PhD G think about the experiment?
summary: PhD G informed the team that the experiment was still not complete, but it looked like the vocal tract length normalization was working beautifully using the warp factors that they computed for the SRI system and just applying them to the ICSI front-end. The PLP was getting basically the same as the MFCC. The team discussed whether they should increase the error rate or do the recognition on automatic segmentations.

query: Summarize the update on transcription.
summary: Transcribers have continued to work past set one and are in the process of being edited. One of the transcribers had a baby, which was an unforeseen side effect of the project. The other two had been putting in a lot of hours up to this point and they were continuing to put in the hours. The team should keep the staff on the leaner side rather than hiring more.

query: Summarize the discussion about meeting data collection
summary: The team had collected sixty-two hours of meeting data so far. The team was working on the directory structure for all of the meeting data and preparing a spreadsheet with start time, the date, the new meeting name, the number of speakers, the duration of the meetings, comments, the transcription status, and a place for comments.

query: Summarize the discussion on the close-talking mikes and pitch features
summary: The team was pleased with the results from the close-talking mikes. The team thought that the pitch features were better than in Switchboard because the pitch processing that was done had much cleaner behavior than the Switchboard telephone bandwidth. However, the team was concerned that the model was not generalizing well because it was not trained on very good features. The professor suggested that the team could improve the model by tweaking the insertion penalty and optimizing the weights.

query: What did the Professor think about the tandem model?
summary: The professor informed the team that there were two problems with the tandem model. The first was that the tandem was not performing as well as expected. The professor thought that it was probably due to the front-end. The second problem was that there was a big DC offset in the model. He thought that they could fix this by adding a high-pass filter.

query: What did the Professor think about the final word error?
summary: The professor explained that the nets were trained with particular normalization and when that got screwed up it could really hurt the model. The team discussed how they could optimize the features for the final word error. The professor suggested that they could do a KLT transform on the combined feature vector. He thought that this might be a good idea.

query: What did the Professor think about noise?
summary: The professor informed the team that the team had started working on the Mississippi State recognizer. The team had downloaded the software and the sample data. The professor informed them that most of the noise was below a hundred hertz, so they should not worry too much about it. However, the professor did want to know what the team was doing about noise. He thought that they should figure out a way to deal with it.

query: What did PhD C think about the delta?
summary: PhD C informed the team that the VAD was used for on-line normalization, and it was used before the delta computation. The delta was 50 milliseconds. There was also an LDA filter, and a hundred hidden units. The team was happy with the results.

query: What did PhD C think about the mismatch problem?
summary: PhD C thought that the team was doing well on the well-matched and the mismatched cases, but it was getting worse on the highly mismatched. The team was surprised that the neural net was getting better recognition when there was more mismatch, as it was the case for the Professor B.

query: What did the professor think about noise compensation?
summary: The professor thought that the model was doing better with noise compensation. He thought that it was because the models were paying attention to the neural net features. The team thought that they could improve the model by improving the training set.

query: What did the professor think about LDA?
summary: The professor thought that LDA was a great idea. He thought that the neural net should be able to do better at the discriminant part than LDA. He also thought that it would be a good idea to put LDA into another neural net.

query: What did the Professor think about silence?
summary: The professor thought that the silence probability was too high. He wanted to know if it was due to the fact that the probability of silence at the output of the network was high. The team thought that they should look at whether they could modify the output probabilities of the neural net based on the silence probabilities. The professor also wanted to learn more about the correlation between silence and speech.

query: Summarize the discussion about the conceptual design.
summary: The first thing to aim for is a fancy look and feel, followed by the technologic technology and the innovations to do with that. The second thing is the easy to use factor. The last thing is fancy appearance and the ease of use. For the electronics, the group decided to go for fruit and vegetable theme and go for a spongy feel. The group also discussed whether to use rubber, plastic, wood or titanium.

query: What did User Interface suggest about the design of the remote control?
summary: User Interface suggested that the remote control could have a central button that users could tap to get to a mode on the television, like changing the brightness of the television or turning on the timer. Users could also scroll around to do the timer or scroll to different channels. The wheel could go through a hundred channels and the power button could even be a long silver thing. The remote control should be easy to manipulate and use.

query: What did the group discuss about the menu button?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the menu button should be on the top of the remote control because it was not necessary to have a button access to change the contrast or something because it just didn't come up every day or something. Project Manager thought that it should be in the output signal to be able to bring it up. User Interface thought it would not be too hard because most of the remotes they had had had the menu buttons, and most people didn't need a button to bring up the menu screen.

query: What did User Interface think of the touch-based graphical interface when discussing the technical features of the remote control?
summary: User Interface thought the touch-based graphical interface was technologically innovative in a way and trendy. It was trendy because the iPods were trendy right now and all the colours were named after fruits and vegetables. Marketing suggested that they could name the material of the remote control after fruits or vegetables. Industrial Designer suggested that the material could be rubber or stress balls. User Interface suggested a hard plastic thing with a spongy area around it. Project Manager thought it could be made of silver because those were their company colours.

query: What did the group discuss about the shape of the remote control?
summary: Marketing proposed to change the hard part of the remote control into a squashy ball, but Industrial Designer rejected this idea because he thought it was not very neat. Project Manager thought it would be nicer to have a drawing because it was neater. User Interface thought the handheld part could be made into a fruit and vegetable part and the squishy part could change shape according to the way the user held it. Industrial Designer also proposed to make it into a single ball shape.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about energy?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested three options of energy: batteries, solar power, and a dynamo. Solar power was not available with the rubber case, so they had to use batteries. The other option was a kinetic thing where you'd basically have to wind it yourself. The dynamo was quite cool because the moment you threw it, it would store loads of energy and you didn't need to buy a battery. The cost was not too much because most of the stuff was pretty cheap though bought in bulk.

query: Summarize the presentation on market trends.
summary: Marketing presented the market trends and suggested that the most important aspect for remote controls were fancy look and feel, technologically innovative and easy to use. The market trends were young, business, kind of range and trendy. Marketing also suggested that fruit and vegetables were going to be the theme for clothes, shoes and furniture this year, and there was a trend towards a spongy feel to materials in contrast to last year.

query: Summarize the discussion about the design of the remote control.
summary: Industrial Designer first presented the main idea of the remote control and the availability of the components they have in stock at the moment. Then, the team discussed the battery options, including the standard double A and triple A, dynamo charging, solar charging and kinetic charging. The team finally reached a consensus that solar charging was the best option because most people had the light on in the room anyway so they could get the TV when they got it. However, the kinetic charging was not necessary because the amount of moving around they would be doing all the time would not charge it up.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the battery life of the remote?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the battery would last for a long time because it was on the wrist so it was moving a lot of the time. However, the solar cells were not very resistant to dropping and the batteries were smaller so they would not last as long.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the circuit design of the remote?
summary: Industrial Designer firstly pointed out that most current remotes use silicone contacts that are really close together and then when users press down on the rubber button, it will connect the circuit and each switch is connected to two different legs on the chip and so sends a different message to the chip, which gets translated by the chip into a code and then it's fired out of this L_E_D in the sequence of on and off bursts.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the rubber cover when talking about the interface designs with the buttons?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that they could make the basic mould out of plastic but have a rubber cover that goes over, which would give the spongy feel and allow them to kind of have different fasciae for the phone. They could arrange the buttons on the screen in a sort of set thing and they could have them like a touch. However, the problem with the rubber cover was that it was flat and so they couldn't do lots of curve things with it.

query: What did the group discuss about the functional design of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the buttons could get lost easily and they would be easy to replace. User Interface thought that a person who switched channels very often or did use a particular function very often would find it very irritating to use a touch-pad, so they could have rubber buttons made of this material which was anti-RSI.

query: What did the team discuss about the design of the flip-top?
summary: Firstly, the team took the input from the previous meeting, especially from the marketing and industrial design, to check on the customer needs and feasibility. Second, they checked into competitors' standard models and found that there was not much variety and too much confusion. Third, they decided to have a G-U-I interface in the middle of the flip-top. Fourth, they would have repetitive buttons which were like volume or channel changing and all could be on the pointing device.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the decision on the kinetic battery and voice recognition.
summary: The group agreed on the kinetic battery and voice recognition. The kinetic battery would be the most common feature across all models and it would not be cheap to re-manufacture them. The group also agreed to take inspiration from fruit colours, like the vibrant colours, red chilli and tomato red. The team also agreed on certain standard buttons, like volume and channel.

query: What did the group discuss about the components of the product?
summary: The group decided to use a black and white LCD screen, rubber as a padding or for the grip, and a variety of designs for the plastic shell. On the top one, there would be a flip-screen, the bottom one would be the LCD and the rubberised buttons.

query: What did Project Manager suggest about the design of the remote control?
summary: Project Manager suggested that the remote control should be made of beige and black, with a rubberised cover that fits into the palm of the hand, rubberised buttons on the bottom side and a fruit and vegetable colour cover in rubber. The cover should be retouchable so that users could change it every time. The remote control could also be used for acupressure and voice recognition.

query: What did Project Manager and Marketing discuss about the whistle when discussing the design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested that the whistle could be incorporated in the design because it was the only one of its kind on the market and the company wanted it to be obvious that it was their product. Project Manager agreed and suggested that they could incorporate the company logo into the design. However, the cost of the whistle was not feasible so they decided to find out more about the cost after the meeting.

query: Summarize the project plan.
summary: Project Manager introduced that they were going to develop a new product, which should be original, trendy and user-friendly. They would use a project method during this development, which consisted of three different design stages. The functional design would search for the user requirements, the conceptual design and the detailed design would be done individually. Then they would discuss the working design.

query: Summarize Project Manager's presentation on the project finance.
summary: Project Manager introduced that the SMARTboard would have a selling price of 25 Euros and a profit of 50 million Euros. It would be sold internationally and produced at a cost of 12.5 Euros per unit.

query: What did the group discuss about the interoperability of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that one remote control should control one or more pieces of equipment, including DVD players, cell phones, video and audio equipment, and the way of communicating with these equipments. User Interface suggested that the remote should work on different TVs or even different devices. However, Project Manager pointed out that they were not developing this product for a specific vendor, so they were going business to consumer.

query: What did the group discuss about the remote control's technical function?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the remote control should be able to change the state of the TV by pressing the button. However, User Interface pointed out that it was quite disturbing when users always had to point directly to the TV, so infrared should be restricted to that. Also, the range should be limited for TV because users were always in the neighbourhood of a TV.

query: What did the group discuss about how the market would respond to the product?
summary: Marketing thought most most things have already been said, like control multiple devices, infrared might be an issue, pointing might be implemented, because lots of devices already use infrared. User Interface suggested that users must feel the buttons for volume or whatever, so it should be visible in dark. Industrial Designer thought it would be nice for a user to have display on this remote control, on which users could see functions. Project Manager agreed, because they want to develop a trendy product.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the cost price of the remote control when discussing the financial part of the project?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the financial part of the project implicates that it's not going to be a high high-end product. Project Manager agreed and pointed out that the cost price of the remote control was very low. However, Industrial Designer thought Bluetooth might be a problem because it's use a lot of time. So Project Manager suggested that they could only light the buttons that are applicable at that moment.
